content: I’m a Ph.D. Candidate in Oceanography at Texas A&M University. My research interests include coastal physical-biological interactions, shelf and river plume dynamics, seasonal hypoxia, and the ecological relevance of different scales of variability in the shelf. I use ROMS (COAWST) as a modeling tool, and Python to analyze model output and observational data.

Tracing variability in the budget balance of bottom water dissolved oxygen in the Texas-Louisiana shelf.

content: Models allow a dynamic estimate of the hypoxic region in the Texas-Louisiana Shelf. While annual summer cruise observations capture a static vision of what is expected to be the largest extent of the season (late July or early August), models simulate the development of the region in time. Although model simulations are not completely accurate, they give an estimation driven by realistic hydrodynamic settings. 20 years of model output capture a wide range of interannual variability.
summary: Relevance of areal extent of hypoxia
title: Hypoxic extent

content: To reproduce variability within the hypoxic region, models need to resolve sub-mesoscale (100 m to 10 km) and mesoscale (10 to 100 km) dynamic processes. Hourly simulations of a simple oxygen parametrization incorporated in a high resolution hydrodynamic model, show the formation and destruction of eddy-like features and fronts in the bottom oxygen structure. Due to the difficulty of sampling, these features have not been fully observed but hinted by high-resolution Acrobat measurements (DiMarco and Zimmerle, 2017).
